stream_context.summary: Kaze returns to active development on Return to Yoshi’s Island during a weekday stream, focusing on (1) toolchain friction around the Fast64/level-export “Upgrader UI,” (2) tracking down an emulator crash caused by a specific coin-formation object, and (3) preproduction for the “retro section” in Course 13—locking in a Super Mario Land 1-inspired black-and-white segment with a fixed-camera, screen-space movement concept and a simple 3D plane model derived from 16x16 sprite reference.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains project-defining constraints for the retro section (pre-Mario-64 rule, SML1 is mandatory, black-and-white aesthetic), a concrete engine limitation shaping level presentation (no area background support → corridor/fog/borders), and a practical stance on emulator support (Project64/GLideN64 as the target).

findings.summary: Kaze notes he did off-stream work to apply basic UV mapping across assets (including a brick texture set), aiming to make wall textures look “half decent” before moving on to the retro section.

Kaze references being “in PR” (a pull request) for the upgraded/tool changes rather than privately requesting them, indicating toolchain updates are being handled through a shared repo workflow with other maintainers.

A persistent crash is traced to a specific coin formation object; removing/selectively disabling coin formations confirms the culprit and resolves the crash, highlighting coin formations as a recurring stability risk in this pipeline.

Kaze confirms the project is using the N64 Expansion Pak memory, describing it as making “everything a little easier,” implying RTYI content/tech targets expanded memory rather than strict stock N64 constraints.

Kaze commits to a pragmatic emulator-support strategy: he primarily targets Project64 with modern GLideN64, arguing every emulator has unique bugs and supporting multiple emulators would multiply workaround effort; he considers Parallel effectively unusable for their needs.
findings.quote: Every emulator is broken as fuck. I just have to pick one emulator and run with it.

findings.summary: For Course 13’s retro segment, Kaze sets a firm rule: only games released before Mario 64 are eligible for references, to preserve the “fits in the time” feeling of an N64-era alternate history.
findings.quote: Only games that released before Mario 64 are eligible.

findings.summary: Kaze makes Super Mario Land 1 inclusion a non-negotiable retro reference (partly driven by his own nostalgia), debating which Land 1 level concept translates best without becoming “the same game, but worse.”

Kaze explores a Land 1-inspired vehicle segment (plane/submarine/space) but favors a fixed-perspective corridor with forced camera and player movement in screen space; enemies approach the camera, creating a rail-shooter-like feel without requiring full “front sprites for everything.”

Engine limitation: true area-background rendering (solid white void) isn’t supported; rather than adding expensive engine support, Kaze chooses a corridor solution (walls/rims) and considers fog/borders to control visibility and keep the aesthetic from looking empty or “ass.”

Repository-wide rendering change: Kaze says he has permanently swapped draw layers 5 and 6 (and then has to reconcile naming/enum mapping), implying a systemic change affecting transparency/decals ordering across levels.

Kaze situates progress: they are in Course 13; the “Space Arcade” and “Papercraft” levels are stated to be the last two major levels remaining after this course. He also mentions Yoshi’s Story was previously considered but cut as “unfitting.”

Kaze describes external pressures shaping output cadence: new parenting time constraints and desire for more income; he plans to stream “basically every day” because he’s efficient working live. He also mentions his parents visiting in Germany for 10 days, consuming time/energy.
findings.quote: I need to work more because I want to make more money. So that's why I'm gonna just stream like basically every day now.

biobak.summary: Biobak appears to be consulted for agreement on retro-game selection (Kaze explicitly checks whether a proposed direction “works”), using chat as real-time validation for direction before committing.

findings.summary: Lilaa provides concrete guidance for updating the tool/plugin via preferences (Kaze follows the step sequence in-stream), helping unblock the “Upgrader UI” update workflow.

During a layer/enum naming confusion, Lilaa (or a collaborator Kaze addresses directly) appears to have renamed items to match the enum, resolving Kaze’s immediate friction and reinforcing the importance of consistent naming for render-layer mapping.
Kaze mentions “run Strygon to update the Upgrader UI,” implying Strygon is a specific script/tool or maintainer involved in the upgrade system Kaze relies on for exporting/engine integration.

key_stories.title: Crash traced to a coin formation object
key_stories.summary: Kaze hits a repeatable crash while testing the level and initially suspects memory or collision complexity. After isolating actors, he identifies a specific coin formation as the culprit and removes targeted coin formations until the crash disappears.
key_stories.challenge: A persistent crash during runtime testing with unclear root cause (could be collision triangles, memory, or an actor).
key_stories.process: He narrows the issue to actors, hypothesizes coin formations, removes multiple coin formations, checks object IDs/notes, and finds the specific formation responsible.
key_stories.outcome: Crash is resolved by removing/fixing the offending coin formation; coin formations are reaffirmed as a high-risk object type to verify early in testing.

key_stories.title: Locking the retro section constraints for Course 13
key_stories.summary: While preparing the ‘retro section,’ Kaze sets rules for what games can be referenced (pre–Mario 64 only) and insists Super Mario Land 1 must be represented. He iterates on how to translate Land 1’s vehicle levels into a compelling N64 segment without requiring costly art tasks like front-facing sprites for everything.
key_stories.challenge: Choosing a retro-game homage that fits the project’s time-period fiction and is feasible with current art/engine constraints.
key_stories.process: He surveys candidate Land 1 levels (submarine/space/plane), evaluates gameplay translation risks (‘same game but worse’), then converges on a forced-perspective corridor with fixed camera and screen-space movement, plus a simple 3D plane model based on 16x16 sprite reference.
key_stories.outcome: A clear direction emerges: SML1 black-and-white aesthetic, fixed camera, corridor/borders/fog to control visibility; avoid heavy sprite-front-facing requirements by using simple 3D enemies/objects where possible.
key_stories.key_quote: Only games that released before Mario 64 are eligible.

open_questions.topic: Toolchain: what exactly is the “Upgrader UI” and what changed in the PR?
open_questions.context: Kaze struggles with an Upgrader UI update flow, follows a specific ‘preferences → check for update → install main’ path, and mentions the changes are being handled via PR. This sounds like a critical part of the export/upgrade pipeline for Fast64/decomp-based workflows.
questions: What is the Upgrader UI responsible for in RTYI’s pipeline (exporting levels, materials, actors, microcode settings, or repo syncing)?
What broke or confused users that prompted this update (and why did Kaze believe ‘if I'm doing it wrong, everyone must be doing it wrong’)?
Who maintains it (Lilaa, Lina, Strygon, others), and how does Kaze coordinate changes—does the team rely on a specific fork/branch for RTYI?

open_questions.topic: Emulator targeting as an implicit platform decision
open_questions.context: Kaze argues Project64 with modern GLideN64 is the practical target; he claims Parallel ‘will literally never work’ for them. This affects accessibility, QA, and how ‘authentic N64’ the final experience is.
questions: Which specific RTYI features/behaviors break on Parallel (rendering, timing, RSP/RDP accuracy, memory behavior, microcode)?
Is real-hardware testing a parallel track, or does Project64 effectively define correctness during development?
Does the project plan to document ‘supported emulator + plugin versions’ at release, and how will you communicate that without alienating players?

open_questions.topic: Course 13 retro section: final gameplay spec and art budget decisions
open_questions.context: Kaze converges on a fixed-camera, screen-space movement corridor concept with black-and-white SML1 aesthetics, but several implementation choices remain open (fog amount, enemy presentation, how to constrain play area visually).
questions: Is the Course 13 SML1 segment ultimately a rail shooter, a pseudo-rail corridor with free movement, or a platforming segment with vehicle flavor?
What is the minimum set of enemies/objects needed for the homage, and how will you avoid ‘front sprite’ requirements—3D models, billboards, voxel art, or simplified sprites?
How do you want players to read the playable space—borders, rim textures, fog, collision rails, or camera framing—and what playtests informed this?

open_questions.context: Kaze says he ‘permanently swapped the draw layers’ and then discovers naming/enum mapping confusion. This sounds like a systemic rendering-order change that could affect transparency, decals, and level authoring rules.
questions: What problem motivated swapping layers 5 and 6 (specific artifact, decal ordering, transparency sorting, performance)?
How many assets/levels were impacted, and did it cause regressions that required manual cleanup?
What is the current authoring rule for level designers/artists so the layer system stays consistent going forward?
